TextJPN: 鹿骨市　興宮警察署
TextENG: Shishibone City　Okinomiya Police Station

TextJPN: 鹿骨市は、地方都市の中では廃れた部類に入る町だった。
TextENG: Shishibone City was, as far as provincial cities went, rather behind the times.

TextJPN: 興宮の町はその中でもさらに山奥の僻地に当たる。
TextENG: Okinomiya, recessed in the mountains, was even more remote.

TextJPN: 四季の変化にも疎く、退屈な時間のまま季節に取り残された…つまらない町。
TextENG: With little change between the seasons, all that was left was the tepid passage of time... it made for a rather drab town.

TextJPN: …観光名所もなく、名産もない。
TextENG: There were no tourist attractions or local delicacies.

TextJPN: 地域産業もひとつ盛り上がりに欠ける、いわゆる映えない町だった。
TextENG: Without even a strong regional industry, it was simply dull.

TextJPN: だが、単調なれど平和な町並みからは、…鬼ヶ淵死守同盟の過激な抵抗を垣間見るのは難しい…。
TextENG: Just looking at the monotonous and peaceful townscape, it was hard to catch a glimpse of the radical resistance of the Onigafuchi Guardians...

TextJPN: 反ダム戦争の最前線に立たされているという興宮警察署も、県警本部で聞いた暗闘の数々を微塵も感じさせない、退屈な雰囲気を漂わせていた。
TextENG: The atmosphere of boredom didn't hint of the Okinomiya Police Station being on the front lines of the dam conflict, nor of the numerous incidents that I heard about at the prefectural headquarters.

TextJPN: 「おはようございます。@k@vS05/00/jimu00002.違反金の納付ですか？」
TextENG: ``Good morning.@k@vS05/00/jimu00002. Are you here to pay a fine?``

TextJPN: 「いえ、公安部の本田屋さんにアポイントがあります。@k@vS05/13/101300051.赤坂とお伝え下さい」
TextENG: ``No, I have an appointment with Hondaya-san from the Public Safety Division.@k@vS05/13/101300051. Please tell him it's Akasaka.``

TextJPN: 「あ、…しし、失礼しました、少々お待ち下さい…」
TextENG: ``Ah... m-my apologies. Please wait a minute...``

TextJPN: 人の顔を見るなり駐車違反だと思い込んでくれた事務員は、かけ慣れない内線番号に戸惑いながら、先方に自分の来訪を伝えていた。
TextENG: The clerk (who thought that I was here for a parking violation at first glance) after fumbling with the unfamiliar extension number, told the person on the line they had a visitor.

TextJPN: 「どうもどうも！@k@vS05/00/104000002.　赤坂さんでいらっしゃいますか、遠路はるばるお疲れさまでした！@k@vS05/00/104000003.　こんな部屋で申し訳ありませんね、応接室をおさえてあったんですがね」
TextENG: ``Welcome, welcome!@k@vS05/00/104000002. Akasaka-san, was it? It must have been tiring travelling out all this way!@k@vS05/00/104000003. Sorry we have to do this here. I tried to reserve a reception room, you see.``

TextJPN: 「議員さんが突然お越しになっちゃったんで追い出されちゃいまして！@k@vS05/00/104000005.　わははははは！」
TextENG: ``But the councillor suddenly woke up and chased me out!@k@vS05/00/104000005. Wahahaha!``

TextJPN: そこは会議室と呼ぶには少々抵抗を感じる、雑多な狭い部屋だった。
TextENG: I would hesitate to call where we were a conference room, as it was very small and cluttered.

TextJPN: …狭い部屋にはぎっしりの着替えロッカーが並び、会議室というよりも、更衣室に設けられた喫煙スペースのような印象だった。
TextENG: ...The cramped space was packed with lockers. I had the impression that it was more of a change room that doubled as one for smoking.

TextJPN: 下品にげらげら笑う、この本田屋という地元公安の幹部は、およそ知的な人物に感じられなかった。
TextENG: Listening to his crude chortles, I didn't get much of a feeling that Hondaya, who was head of the local Public Safety Division, was much of an intellectual.

TextJPN: だがその分、自らの勘と経験に揺るぎない自信を持つことがわかる。
TextENG: But I knew that, in exchange, he had both experience and absolute confidence in his instincts.

TextJPN: 「ご多忙中、突然お邪魔して申し訳ありませんでした。@k@vS05/13/101300053.警視庁から参りました赤坂と申します。@k@vS05/13/101300054.よろしくお願いします」
TextENG: ``I apologize for interrupting you during such a busy time.@k@vS05/13/101300053. I'm Akasaka from the Metropolitan Police Department.@k@vS05/13/101300054. Pleased to make your acquaintance.``

TextJPN: 「公安部の本田屋です。@k@vS05/00/104000007.よろしくよろしく。@k@vS05/00/104000008.県警暴対の山海部長から協力を惜しむなと脅されとりますので。@k@vS05/00/104000009.わははははは！」
TextENG: ``Hondaya from the Public Safety Division.@k@vS05/00/104000007. Nice to meetcha.@k@vS05/00/104000008. I was threatened by Sankai from the Prefectural Gangbusters to be generous with my cooperation.@k@vS05/00/104000009. Wahahaha!``

TextJPN: 「暴対？@k@vS05/13/101300056.　県警の暴力団対策本部ですか？」
TextENG: ``Gangbusters?@k@vS05/13/101300056. You mean the Prefectural Crime Prevention Division?``

TextJPN: 「うちじゃあ、鬼ヶ淵死守の連中は暴力団の延長に位置づけてますんでね。@k@vS05/00/104000011.あれを善意の住民運動だなんてあんた、トーシロもいいとこですわ、わははははは！」
TextENG: ``You see, we're treating the Onigafuchi Guardians as an extension of the local yakuza.@k@vS05/00/104000011. You'd have to be a newbie if you think they're just a residential protest group, wahahaha!``

TextJPN: 県警でも、鬼ヶ淵死守同盟が地域の暴力団と連携していると言っていた。
TextENG: They said at the prefectural office too that the Onigafuchi Guardians was linked to the local mob.

TextJPN: 確か、組長が村の重鎮の婿養子だとかで…。
TextENG: If I recall correctly, the adopted son of somebody influential was a lieutenant in that gang...

TextJPN: 「そりゃ逆。@k@vS05/00/104000013.全然逆ですよ、暴力団の活動があって、それに住民団体が大義名分みたいにくっついてると、そういう風に考えて下さい。@k@vS05/00/104000014.逆、逆。@k@vS05/00/104000015.わははははは！」
TextENG: ``It's the other way around.@k@vS05/00/104000013. The complete opposite. The yakuza put up the protest group as a front to justify their actions. Just think of it like that.@k@vS05/00/104000014. Completely the other way around.@k@vS05/00/104000015. Wahahaha!``

TextJPN: 本田屋氏が豪快に笑い転げる。
TextENG: Hondaya was just about rolling with laughter.

TextJPN: …県警での情報とは若干異なるが、この手の情報は地域に密着した人間の方がよほど詳しいものだ。
TextENG: ...This was slightly different than the info given to me at the prefectural office, but somebody embedded locally would be more knowledgable.

TextJPN: 私たちがこうしたやりとりをしている間にも、時々、刑事らしき人間が何人か入ってきては、着替えをしていた。
TextENG: While we were talking, occasionally some people who seemed to be detectives would come in and change.

TextJPN: …そんな内のひとりが、本田屋氏の大笑いに気付き、こちらに歩み寄ってきた。
TextENG: ...One of those individuals, noticing Hondaya's guffaws, came up to us.

TextJPN: 「何の話をしてるかと思えば。@k@vS05/11/100700002.んっふっふっふっふ！」
TextENG: ``I was wondering what you guys were talking about.@k@vS05/11/100700002. Nfu fu fu fu!``

TextJPN: 「おー、蔵ちゃん！@k@vS05/00/104000017.　ちょうどよかった、蔵ちゃんも入ってよ。@k@vS05/00/104000018.こちら、はるばる東京の警視庁からお見えになった赤坂警部」
TextENG: ``Oh, Kura-chan!@k@vS05/00/104000017. Perfect timing, why don't you join us?@k@vS05/00/104000018. This here is Inspector Akasaka, who came all the way from the Tokyo Police Department.``

TextJPN: 「警部だなんて…！@k@vS05/13/101300058.　ま、まだまだ新米です。@k@vS05/13/101300059.赤坂です、よろしくお願いします…」
TextENG: ``An Inspector?@k@vS05/13/101300058. I-I'm still a rookie.@k@vS05/13/101300059. My name is Akasaka, pleased to meet you...``

TextJPN: 「初々しいのがいいですねぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700004.採用は今年ですか？@k@vS05/11/100700005.　んっふっふっふ！」
TextENG: ``It must be nice to be so fresh-faced.@k@vS05/11/100700004. Did they hire you this year?@k@vS05/11/100700005. Nfu fu fu!``

TextJPN: 見くびられるかなと思ったので、愛想笑いだけにして、答えないことにする…。
TextENG: I couldn't help but think I was being ridiculed, so I only responded with a forced smile...

TextJPN: この新しく現れた男も、本田屋氏同様、勘と経験に強い自信を持つ叩き上げタイプであることが見て取れた。@k…この手の人間は、…本当は好きではない。
TextENG: I could tell that this new person was like Hondaya, the type who had confidence in their instincts and experience.@k ...I really didn't like those types of people.

TextJPN: 「赤坂さんにもご紹介します。@k@vS05/00/104000020.こちらは刑事部の大石くん。@k@vS05/00/104000021.赤坂さんがお問い合わせのＳ号の件なら、彼が詳しいです」
TextENG: ``Let me introduce you, Akasaka-san.@k@vS05/00/104000020. This is Ooishi-kun from our Investigative Department.@k@vS05/00/104000021. Regarding the S File you were asking about, he's familiar with it.``

TextJPN: 「園崎のＳ。@k@vS05/11/100700007.Ｓ号ってのはですね、園崎家が関連してる件を示す…、まぁ暗号みたいなもんなんです」
TextENG: ``S for Sonozaki.@k@vS05/11/100700007. If something is an S File, it means it has something to do with the Sonozaki family... it's something of a codename.``

TextJPN: 園崎？
TextENG: Sonozaki?

TextJPN: …そう言えば、県警本部で読んだ資料の中に、園崎姓を持った人物名がいくつか出てきたことを思い出す。
TextENG: ...Come to think of it, I remembered when I was poring over the documents at headquarters, there were quite a few people with the last name Sonozaki popping up.

TextJPN: 「…確か、園崎氏は鬼ヶ淵死守同盟の役員でしたね。@k@vS05/13/101300062.確か会計だったと思います」
TextENG: ``...If I remember right, there's a Sonozaki who is one of the executives of the Onigafuchi Guardians.@k@vS05/13/101300062. I'm pretty sure they're the treasurer.``

TextJPN: 私がすらすらと園崎氏の役職を即答したのを見て、二人は目を丸くする。
TextENG: The two of them were surprised when I rattled off what post that Sonozaki held.

TextJPN: …それからややしばらくして、二人して大笑いした。
TextENG: ...After a moment, both of them erupted into laughter.

TextJPN: 「赤坂さんでしたっけ？@k@vS05/11/100700009.　なっはっはっは！@k@vS05/11/100700010.　あなたお勉強家さんですねぇ！@k@vS05/11/100700011.　ひょっとして同盟の連中の主要人物、全部暗記してるんじゃ？@k@vS05/11/100700012.　なっはっはっはっは！」
TextENG: ``Akasaka-san was it?@k@vS05/11/100700009. Na ha ha ha!@k@vS05/11/100700010. You're quite the studious one!@k@vS05/11/100700011. Could it be you've memorized all of the central figures in the Alliance?@k@vS05/11/100700012. Na ha ha ha ha!``

TextJPN: 「…暗記、というほどではありませんが、一応、鬼ヶ淵死守同盟の幹部リストは一読しました」
TextENG: ``I wouldn't say memorized, exactly, but I've at least read the list of Onigafuchi Guardians executives.``

TextJPN: 「んっふっふ！@k@vS05/11/100700014.　じゃあ、会長と副会長は？」
TextENG: ``Nfu fu!@k@vS05/11/100700014. Then, who are the president and vice-president?``

TextJPN: 「会長は現雛見沢村村長の公由喜一郎氏。@k@vS05/13/101300065.副会長は町会神社部長の古手氏。@k@vS05/13/101300066.会計が園崎お魎氏で、会計監査は牧野氏。@k@vS05/13/101300067.共闘部長が公由義郎氏、広報部長が園崎禎夫氏…、」
TextENG: ``The president is the mayor of Hinamizawa, Kiichirou Kimiyoshi.@k@vS05/13/101300065. The vice-president is the priest of the local shrine, Furude.@k@vS05/13/101300066. The treasurer is Oryou Sonozaki, the auditor is Makino.@k@vS05/13/101300067. The liason is Yoshirou Kimiyoshi, the PR Head is Sadao Sonozaki...``

TextJPN: 「なっはっは…！！@k@vS05/11/100700016.　赤坂さん、あなたなかなかやりますねぇ！@k@vS05/11/100700017.　給料安いけど、ウチに来ません？@k@vS05/11/100700018.　ウチに一番必要で、一番いないタイプですよ」
TextENG: ``Na ha ha...!!@k@vS05/11/100700016. Akasaka-san, you're pretty good!@k@vS05/11/100700017. The pay sucks, but you want to work here?@k@vS05/11/100700018. You're just the type we're looking for.``

TextJPN: 「んっふっふっふ！@k@vS05/11/100700020.　…で、ちなみに園崎禎夫は青年部長なんです。@k@vS05/11/100700021.惜しいですね、広報部長は園崎忠敬。んっふっふっふ！」
TextENG: ``Nfu fu fu!@k@vS05/11/100700020. ...By the way, Sadao Sonozaki is head of the Youth Department.@k@vS05/11/100700021. So close! The Head of Public Relations is actually Tadataka Sonozaki. Euheh heh heh!``

TextJPN: 褒められている気がせず、少し不愉快な気分になった。
TextENG: Feeling like I wasn't being complimented at all, I started settling into an uncomfortable mood.

TextJPN: …だが、自分の今回の仕事に、一番欠かせない人間であることがますます分かり、その気持ちをぐっと堪える。
TextENG: ...However, I was becoming more and more aware that I was the weakest link in this investigation, so I just had to bear with it.

TextJPN: そんな感情を表情に出したつもりはないが、老獪な刑事たちには筒抜けなようだった。
TextENG: I didn't mean for that feeling to show up on my face, but the crafty detectives didn't let that slip by.

TextJPN: 「なっはっはっは！@k@vS05/11/100700023.　馬鹿にしたつもりはないんです。@k@vS05/11/100700024.…お詫びと言っちゃあなんですが、何でしたら村を実際にご案内しましょう」
TextENG: ``Na ha ha ha!@k@vS05/11/100700023. I didn't mean to make fun of you.@k@vS05/11/100700024. ...To make up for it, why don't I show you around the village?``

TextJPN: 土地勘のまったくない自分には助かる…。@k願ってもない申し出だった。
TextENG: For somebody with no feel for the area like me, it would be a great help.@k I couldn't have asked for more.

TextJPN: 「鬼ヶ淵死守同盟ってのは、結局、雛見沢村の対外的な別称に過ぎません。@k@vS05/11/100700026.…村を知ることが、あなたのお仕事の近道だと思いますよ。@k@vS05/11/100700027.…いかがです？」
TextENG: ``In the end, the Onigafuchi Guardians is nothing more than an alias Hinamizawa is using to deal with the outside world.@k@vS05/11/100700026. ...I think getting to know the village would speed up your work.@k@vS05/11/100700027. ...How about it?``

TextJPN: 住民運動はつまるところ、地域勢力のことだ。
TextENG: The residential movement, in other words, held influence over the whole region.

TextJPN: 運動のリーダーはすなわち勢力のリーダー。@k地域の考え方がそのまま運動の性格となる。
TextENG: So the leader of the movement was the leader of that influence.@k Just like that, the thought processes in the region would become the overall personality of the movement.

TextJPN: …大石氏の言うとおり、鬼ヶ淵死守同盟という反ダム地域勢力を知るには、村を知るのが一番の近道。
TextENG: ...Just like Ooishi had said, in order to learn what they were really like, this regional force behind the dam protests, getting to know the village was the quickest way.

TextJPN: 「…よろしくお願いします！」
TextENG: ``...If you would!``

TextJPN: 間髪入れずに頷き返すと、大石氏は満足げに笑って立ち上がった…。
TextENG: Nodding back without skipping a beat, Ooshi laughed in satisfaction and stood up.

TextJPN: 県警本部や、本田屋氏の情報を鵜呑みにするなら、…自分の立場がバレれば、身の危険もあるかもしれない。
TextENG: If I took the information I learned at the prefectural office and from Hondaya to heart... if my position was exposed, my personal safety was at risk.

TextJPN: 相手は個人への脅迫、暴力等のあらゆる攻撃を辞さない過激な団体だ。
TextENG: The opponent was an extremist group that had no qualms about using threats or violence against somebody.

TextJPN: 自分の個人情報が漏洩すれば、身の危険は勤務時間外にまで及ぶことは想像に難しくない…。
TextENG: If my personal info was leaked, it wouldn't be hard to imagine that I'd be in danger, whether on the job or not...

TextJPN: …そう思うと、少しの緊張を感じた。
TextENG: ...Thinking that, I felt a little nervous.

TextJPN: 「連中は、顔覚えるの早いですからねぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700029.私と一緒にいるところを見られると多分、いろいろあなたのお仕事に差し支えると思います。@k@vS05/11/100700030.月並みですがね、こいつを身に付けておいて下さい」
TextENG: ``These guys are quick to remember faces.@k@vS05/11/100700029. If you're seen with me, they'll probably do a lot to hinder your work.@k@vS05/11/100700030. This might be a little cliche, but put these on.``

TextJPN: 大石氏は、野球帽とサングラスとマスクという、あからさまに不審な小道具を用意してくれた。
TextENG: Ooshi handed me an incredibly suspicious disguise comprised of a baseball cap, sunglasses, and a mask.

TextJPN: 暑苦しくて嫌だが、大石氏の忠告は多分、的を射ている。@k…そう思い、ありがたく身に着けることにする。
TextENG: I didn't want to get all hot and stuffy, but Ooishi's warning was probably right on the money.@k ...Considering that, I put them on with appreciation.

TextJPN: あまりの不審な身なりに、大石氏は苦笑をしていた…。
TextENG: I looked so suspicious that Ooishi had to smile wryly...

TextJPN: 「…どこまで話しましたかねぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700032.…えぇっと…」
TextENG: ``...How much did I tell you again?@k@vS05/11/100700032. ...Let's see...``

TextJPN: 「御三家という旧家が村を支配している、というところまでです」
TextENG: ``To the part where you were talking about how these three ancient families control the village.``

TextJPN: 鬼ヶ淵死守同盟とは、すなわち雛見沢村そのものであるということ。
TextENG: The Onigafuchi Guardians was the same as the village of Hinamizawa itself.

TextJPN: つまり、同盟の幹部はそのまま村の幹部という図式になるということは、さっきの本田屋氏からも聞いた。
TextENG: Meaning, there was a direct correlation between being an executive in the Alliance and being a leader in the village, as Hondaya had told me a short time ago.

TextJPN: 村を御三家と言う旧家が支配しているのなら、@k…鬼ヶ淵死守同盟を支配しているのも、その御三家という旧家…ということになる。
TextENG: If the village was ruled by three ancient families...@k then it would mean the Onigafuchi Guardians was ruled by those same three families.

TextJPN: 「県警の資料には何て書いてありました？@k@vS05/11/100700034.　死守同盟のリーダー格とかそういうことについて」
TextENG: ``What did the documents at the prefectural office say?@k@vS05/11/100700034. About the leader of the Guardians or whatnot.``

TextJPN: …我々の扱う資料は一応、部外秘だ。
TextENG: ...The documents I was using were classified.

TextJPN: 大石の問いかけに答えることは守秘義務違反になる。
TextENG: If I responded to Ooishi's question it'd be a breach of security.

TextJPN: …だが、恐らく。
TextENG: ...However, most likely...

TextJPN: 県警本部のどんな資料よりも、この男の方が事情に精通していると判断した私は、答えることにした。
TextENG: This man, I judged, was more well-versed in the situation than any of the documents at the prefectural police department, so I decided to answer him.

TextJPN: 「同盟の会長は、現村長の公由喜一郎と」
TextENG: ``That the president of the Alliance is the current mayor of the village, Kiichirou Kimiyoshi.``

TextJPN: 大石氏はそれを聞いて、小さく笑い捨てた。
TextENG: Ooishi, upon hearing that, let out a small chuckle.

TextJPN: 大石がそのように尋ね、資料通りに答えた内容を笑い捨てたとなると。@k…実際には違う、ということになる。
TextENG: For him to ask like that, and to laugh at the answer as it was recorded in the documents...@k ...meant that wasn't the case in reality.

TextJPN: 「…では…公由氏以外の影の人物がいる、ということですね。@k@vS05/13/101300073.県警の持つ、いや、一般的な情報とは異なり」
TextENG: ``...So then... that means there's somebody else other than Kimiyoshi behind the scenes.@k@vS05/13/101300073. Contrary to what the prefectural office thinks, or rather, what is commonly known.``

TextJPN: 「んっふっふ…。@k@vS05/11/100700036.公由のじいさんなんて、ただのお飾りですよ。@k@vS05/11/100700037.そもそもこの村じゃ、村長なんてポスト自体も形式だけなんです」
TextENG: ``Nfu fu...@k@vS05/11/100700036. Old man Kimiyoshi is nothing more than a figurehead.@k@vS05/11/100700037. In the first place, the post of mayor in that village is nothing more than ceremonial.``

TextJPN: 「つまり、…同盟も村も、本当の意味で支配している別の存在がいる…ということですね？@k@vS05/13/101300075.　それが先ほど仰られていた御三家…という存在ですか？」
TextENG: ``In other words... there's something else in charge of both the Alliance and the village?@k@vS05/13/101300075. Would that be the three families we just talked about?``

TextJPN: 「まぁ、そのあたりはこれからご説明します。@k@vS05/11/100700039.…んっふっふっふ！」
TextENG: ``Well, I'll explain that part right now.@k@vS05/11/100700039. ...Nfu fu fu!``

TextJPN: 突然、車が@|@yガクン！　…と揺れた。
TextENG: All of a sudden, with a@|@y 'thunk', the car suddenly lurched.

TextJPN: 舗装道路が切れ、砂利道に変わった。@kそれと同時に、…窓の外の景色も一変した。
TextENG: The paved road had given way to a gravel one.@k At the same time, the scenery outside the window changed.

TextJPN: 『雛見沢ダム計画断固撤回』
TextENG: ``The Hinamizawa Dam Project Must Be Withdrawn``

TextJPN: 『恥を知れ日和見県知事！　打倒中央集権体制！』
TextENG: ``Overthrow the Shameless Puppet of a Governor!``

TextJPN: 『ダムに沈めるな雛見沢の自然！』
TextENG: ``The Dam Will Submerge the Natural Beauty of Hinamizawa!``

TextJPN: 『悪辣なるダムから村を守れ！』
TextENG: ``Protect the Village from the Unethical Dam!``

TextJPN: 『怨念！　オヤシロさまの祟り！』
TextENG: ``Fear the Wrath of Oyashiro-sama's Curse!``

TextJPN: 『ダム粉砕！　役人は帰れ！』
TextENG: ``Demolish the Dam! Those Involved Must Go Away!``

TextJPN: 『建設事務所は話し合いに応じよ！』
TextENG: ``The Construction Office Must Respond!``

TextJPN: 『工事責任者は談判に臨め！』
TextENG: ``The Construction Office Manager Must Negotiate With Us!``

TextJPN: 看板、幟旗、…そういったものが沿道にひしめいていた…。
TextENG: Signs and banners crowded the roadside...

TextJPN: 書きなぐったような筆の文字が、それだけで読む者を威圧する。
TextENG: Even reading the brush-scrawled words was daunting.

TextJPN: そう、…まさにさっきの舗装道路の途切れは、国境だった。
TextENG: It was as though where the road just changed was a border with a different country.

TextJPN: …その時、突然の急ブレーキに驚かされる。
TextENG: ...At that moment, I was startled by the car suddenly braking.

TextJPN: 見ると…何と、道を塞ぐようにバリケードが設けられていた。
TextENG: Looking ahead... a barricade had been erected.

TextJPN: ヘルメットとマスクで顔を幾重にも隠した活動家のような身なりの人々が５～６人、道を塞ぎ、停まれ停まれと怒鳴り声をあげていた。
TextENG: About 5 or 6 protestors, wearing masks and helmets to hide their faces, were blocking the road, yelling at us angrily to stop.
``...W-What is this!?@k@vS05/13/101300077. A checkpoint!?``
``Hmph.@k@vS05/11/100700041. ...These guys never learn.``

TextJPN: 大石は鼻で笑いながら窓を開けて、身を乗り出した。
TextENG: Ooishi snorted as he rolled down the window and leaned out.

TextJPN: 「…おいおいおい、あんたら、ダメだよこんなとこで道を塞いじゃあ」
TextENG: ``Hey hey hey, you guys, you can't be blocking the road like this here.``

TextJPN: 大石氏が悪意ある笑みを浮かべながら一瞥すると、男たちは明らかに怯んだようだった。
TextENG: As Ooishi glared at them with a malicious laugh, they visibly faltered.

TextJPN: 「…道、開けて下さいな。@k@vS05/11/100700044.それじゃ通れないでしょ。@k@vS05/11/100700045.んっふっふっふ！」
TextENG: ``...Clear the way.@k@vS05/11/100700044. We can't get by like this.@k@vS05/11/100700045. Nfu fu fu!``

TextJPN: …まさか大石の車だったとは…。@kそういう狼狽が、彼らのうろたえようから見て取れた。
TextENG: ...Who would have thought it was Ooishi's car...@k That panicked thought seemed to make them lose their presence of mind.

TextJPN: 「…お、大石刑事の車とわかってればこんなご無礼はしなかったんですがね。@k@vS05/00/104600002.…大石刑事、いつもの車はどうされました？@k@vS05/00/104600003.　車検ですか？」
TextENG: ``...Ah, if we had known it was your car, Detective Ooishi, we wouldn't have been so rude.@k@vS05/00/104600002. ...Detective, what happened to your usual car?@k@vS05/00/104600003. Is it in for maintenance?``

TextJPN: 「そんなところです。@k@vS05/11/100700047.代車ってのは、どうにも馴染みませんねぇ、んっふっふっふ！」
TextENG: ``Something like that.@k@vS05/11/100700047. I just can't get used to this car they loaned me, nfu fu fu!``

TextJPN: …短い会話から、普段、大石氏が使う車のナンバーを彼らが熟知していることを知る。
TextENG: ...Judging from their brief conversation, I could guess that they were familiar with the license plate of the car Ooishi normally used.

TextJPN: つまり、警察車両だと知っていたら、バリケードを隠していた…ということだ。
TextENG: In other words, if they knew the car belonged to the police, they would have hidden the barricade.

TextJPN: 彼らがやっている行為は明らかに、路上の往来妨害。@k犯罪に他ならない。
TextENG: What they were doing was obviously obstruction of traffic.@k A blatant crime.

TextJPN: 「…そっちの怪しい男は誰です？@k@vS05/00/104600005.　あんた、顔を見せてくれませんか？」
TextENG: ``...Who's that suspicious guy?@k@vS05/00/104600005. You, could you show us your face?``

TextJPN: サングラスにマスクという、あからさまに怪しい身なりをしている私に、男が威嚇するような眼差しを向ける。
TextENG: The man glared at me menacingly. Wearing a mask and sunglasses made me look particularly dubious.

TextJPN: …顔を見せないと無用のトラブルに巻き込まれる…？@k　どうしたものか大石氏をうかがう…。
TextENG: ...Would not showing my face get me into some unnecessary trouble...?@k I turned to Ooishi to see what I should do...

TextJPN: 「彼の顔は勘弁してあげてください。@k@vS05/11/100700049.まだまだ新米でシャイなんですからね、んっふっふ！」
TextENG: ``Give him a break.@k@vS05/11/100700049. He's still a shy little rookie, nfu fu!``

TextJPN: 「……不審な輩じゃないか、確認しようってだけです。@k@vS05/00/104600007.…最近の雛見沢は物騒ですからねぇ」
TextENG: ``...We just wanted to make sure he wasn't anybody suspicious.@k@vS05/00/104600007. ...Hinamizawa has been in a bit of a stir as of late.``

TextJPN: 「なっはっはっは！@k@vS05/11/100700051.　あんたの家、鏡、歪んでるのと違います？@k@vS05/11/100700052.　あんたのその面の方が、よーっぽど不審ですよ？@k@vS05/11/100700053.　なっはっはっはっはっは！」
TextENG: ``Na ha ha ha!@k@vS05/11/100700051. Have you looked at yourself in the mirror?@k@vS05/11/100700052. That mask you're wearing is way more suspicious!@k@vS05/11/100700053. Na ha ha ha ha ha!``

TextJPN: 男たちと大石氏は、愛想笑いを交えながら気さくそうに会話をしていたが…。
TextENG: The men and Ooishi continued to talk like that, feigning smiles at one another...

TextJPN: …独特の、火薬のような緊張感の臭いは終始、鼻を離れなかった。
TextENG: ...However, from the beginning to the end, I couldn't get over the feeling I was sitting on a powderkeg.

TextJPN: 「ゴミの不法投棄車両、まだ減らないんですか？@k@vS05/11/100700055.　お宅たちも本当に朝晩、大変ですねぇ」
TextENG: ``Has the number of trucks illegally dumping still not decreased?@k@vS05/11/100700055. It's a real hassle dealing with it all the time.``

TextJPN: 「警察の方にもご理解とご協力を頂けて助かりますよ…。はははは…」
TextENG: ``If the police could understand and cooperate it would really help... hahahaha...``

TextJPN: そんな話をしている内に、バリケードがどかされ、車一台分が通れるくらいの隙間が出来た。
TextENG: During that conversation, the barricade was moved, leaving a gap wide enough for a single car to get through.

TextJPN: 大石氏はクラクションを小さく一回鳴らすと、車はそろりそろりと走り出した。
TextENG: Ooishi lightly honked the horn once, and began to roll the car forward.

TextJPN: 車の背中には、男たちの敵意に満ちた眼差しが送られているのが、バックミラー越しに見えた…。
TextENG: I could see the men's antagonistic glares at the back of the car in the rearview mirror...

TextJPN: 「何ですか、さっきのは。@k@vS05/13/101300079.勝手に公道を封鎖するなんて…！」
TextENG: ``What was that just now?@k@vS05/13/101300079. Blocking a public road like that!``

TextJPN: 「もちろん犯罪ですよ。@k@vS05/11/100700057.目くじら立てても始まりませんがね。@k@vS05/11/100700058.んっふっふっふ！」
TextENG: ``Of course it's a crime.@k@vS05/11/100700057. Still, if you get worked up over that, it'll never end.@k@vS05/11/100700058. Nfu fu fu!``

TextJPN: 「連中の主張じゃですね、村内に不法投棄をするトラックが出没するって言うんです。@k@vS05/11/100700060.それを封じ込めるために不審車両を検問してるって話だそうで」
TextENG: ``Those guys, see, claim there's an infestation of trucks illegally dumping in the village.@k@vS05/11/100700060. Their story goes that in order to stop that, they're halting suspicious vehicles for inspection.``

TextJPN: 「不法投棄？@k@vS05/13/101300081.　産廃を勝手に捨てようとする悪徳業者のことですか…？」
TextENG: ``Illegal dumping?@k@vS05/13/101300081. Like corrupt contractors just tossing industrial waste away?``

TextJPN: 「警察が何の手も打たないから、自分たちで自衛するっていう論法でしてね。@k@vS05/11/100700062.…まぁ、産廃なんて話はどうせ自演だからどうでもいいんですがね」
TextENG: ``Their line of argument is that if the police aren't going to do anything about it, they'll take matters into their own hands.@k@vS05/11/100700062. ...Well, the industrial waste is just something they're doing by themselves anyways.``

TextJPN: 「自演？」
TextENG: ``By themselves?``

TextJPN: 「連中、うまい作戦なんですよ。@k@vS05/11/100700064.ダム現場にですね、工事妨害のために産廃ゴミを自分たちでばら撒いてるんです。@k@vS05/11/100700065.…で、それを悪徳業者のせいってことにして、臨検を設置すると」
TextENG: ``They have a pretty good strategy.@k@vS05/11/100700064. You see, in order to hinder construction, they've spread industrial waste over by the dam site.@k@vS05/11/100700065. ...Then, blaming it on corrupt contractors, they start instituting these inspections.``

TextJPN: 「それで、工事車両をいちいち足止めして、チクチクと妨害してる、ってわけなんです。@k@vS05/11/100700067.んっふっふっふ！」
TextENG: ``There, they stop every construction vehicle coming through and interfere with them as much as possible.@k@vS05/11/100700067. Nfu fu fu!``

TextJPN: 「……鬼ヶ淵死守同盟の、抵抗運動のひとつ、というわけですね」
TextENG: ``...So then, it's one of the methods the Onigafuchi Guardians is using.``

TextJPN: 「多分、今の検問でこの車のナンバーが割れましたからね。@k@vS05/11/100700069.…もうこの先には一切、検問の真似事はないと思います」
TextENG: ``With that inspection just now, this car's license plate has probably been recorded.@k@vS05/11/100700069. ...It shouldn't get stopped from here on out.``

TextJPN: 「…連中も、私を怒らせると得をしないことだけは、よぉく骨身に染みているようですからねぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700071.なっはっはっはっは！」
TextENG: ``...Those guys know very well not to get me angry.@k@vS05/11/100700071. Na ha ha ha ha!``

TextJPN: 「この車が工事関係車両だと知れるとですね。@k@vS05/11/100700073.さんざん検問で足止めを食らうばかりか、投石や鉄釘のばら撒きなんかも食らうって噂です。@k@vS05/11/100700074.…あなたも、身元が割れないようにせいぜい気をつけた方がいいですよ？」
TextENG: ``See, rumor is that if they figure a car is related to the construction in some way,@k@vS05/11/100700073. not only would there be checkpoints stopping it at every turn, but they'd be throwing rocks and planting road spikes as well.@k@vS05/11/100700074. ...It's best you be careful so you're not identified.``

TextJPN: 「公安なんてバレたら、どんな目に遭うやら…。@k@vS05/11/100700076.んっふっふっふ…！」
TextENG: ``If they find out you're from Public Safety, who knows what you'll suffer through...@k@vS05/11/100700076. Nfu fu fu!``

TextJPN: 大石氏は、まるで楽しいことのよう話すが、こちらはとても笑えるような心境ではなかった…。
TextENG: Ooishi was acting like we were talking about something fun, but for me it was no laughing matter...

TextJPN: 「…まるで、どこぞの内戦の国に迷い込んだような錯覚です」
TextENG: ``...It almost feels like we've wandered into a civil war in the Middle East.``

TextJPN: 「なっはっはっはっはっは！@k@vS05/11/100700078.　あんた、そりゃあーうまい言い方です。@k@vS05/11/100700079.今、言われたのはまさにその通り」
TextENG: ``Na ha ha ha ha ha!@k@vS05/11/100700078. That's a good way of putting it.@k@vS05/11/100700079. It's pretty much just what you said.``

TextJPN: 大石氏は、…にやぁっと…凄むように笑いながら、こちらに振り返って言った。
TextENG: Ooishi turned to me with a grin and menacing laugh.

TextJPN: 「ここはね、戦争地帯なんですよ」
TextENG: ``You see, this here's a warzone.``

TextJPN: 田んぼの中の一本道のようなところで、車は少し速度を落とした。
TextENG: The car slowed down a bit as it went down a narrow road through some farmland.

TextJPN: 「あそこの森の中に家があるのが見えます？@k@vS05/11/100700082.　古い感じの」
TextENG: ``You see that house in that forest over there?@k@vS05/11/100700082. That antiquated one.``

TextJPN: 大石氏が指差す向こうを見ると、…確かに言うとおりの古い合掌造りの家が見えた。
TextENG: Looking at where Ooishi was pointing, there certainly was an old, traditionally-designed house.

TextJPN: 「あれが村長の公由のじいさんの家です。@k@vS05/11/100700084.公由本家とも言いますなぁ。@k@vS05/11/100700085.分家筋が多いですから。@k@vS05/11/100700086.御三家のひとつに当たります」
TextENG: ``That belongs to the mayor, old man Kimiyoshi.@k@vS05/11/100700084. You could say it belongs to the main Kimiyoshi house as well.@k@vS05/11/100700085. There's a lot of branches,@k@vS05/11/100700086. but they'd be one of the Three Families.``

TextJPN: 「…御三家。@k@vS05/13/101300087.…雛見沢村を支配している旧家ですね？」
TextENG: ``...The Three Families.@k@vS05/13/101300087. ...The ancient families that control Hinamizawa?``

TextJPN: 「そうそう。@k@vS05/11/100700088.んで、もうひとつが古手家。@k@vS05/11/100700089.こっちは分家どころか、もう神主一家しか残ってませんがね」
TextENG: ``That's right.@k@vS05/11/100700088. And, one of the others is the Furude family.@k@vS05/11/100700089. Their house doesn't even have a single branch, as all that's left is the head priest's family.``

TextJPN: 「…ちょうどあっちの方にね、神社がありまして。@k@vS05/11/100700091.そこの神主をしています。@k@vS05/11/100700092.ちなみにね、死守同盟の事務所はその神社の敷地内にあります」
TextENG: ``...Right over there, there's the shrine.@k@vS05/11/100700091. He's the priest there.@k@vS05/11/100700092. By the way, the Guardians's office is on the grounds of that shrine.``

TextJPN: 鬼ヶ淵死守同盟の事務所…。@k…相手を敵とするなら、まさに本拠地と言える。
TextENG: The office of the Onigafuchi Guardians...@k ...if these guys were the enemy, that would make the shrine their stronghold.

TextJPN: 「そこを見ることはできますか？」
TextENG: ``Can we go look over there?``

TextJPN: 「神社は古手家の私有地でね。@k@vS05/11/100700094.警察と言えど、令状がないと踏み込めません。@k@vS05/11/100700095.…連中のバックには村の息のかかった議員もいますからねぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700096.…警察にも強いところと弱いところがある、ってことです」
TextENG: ``The shrine is the Furude family's private property, you see.@k@vS05/11/100700094. Being police, we can't set foot there without a warrant.@k@vS05/11/100700095. See, they've got a member of the Diet with ties to the village backing them up.@k@vS05/11/100700096. ...Basically, being the police has its strengths and weaknesses.``

TextJPN: 「御三家、とは言ってもですね。@k@vS05/11/100700098.…そりゃあだいぶ大昔のことなんだそうです。@k@vS05/11/100700099.大昔はその御三家ってのが合議して、村のいろいろなことを決めてたらしいですなぁ」
TextENG: ``Well, even when we talk about the Three Families...@k@vS05/11/100700098. that's something from a long time ago.@k@vS05/11/100700099. Way back when, those three families used to hold councils to decide things about the village.``

TextJPN: 「ということは、…今は違うということですね？」
TextENG: ``Meaning... it's different now?``

TextJPN: 「……あんた、いちいち察しがいいですねぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700101.さぁすが高学歴。@k@vS05/11/100700102.んっふっふっふ！」
TextENG: ``...You've got a pretty good nose.@k@vS05/11/100700101. That's what I expect from an academic.@k@vS05/11/100700102. Nfu fu fu!``

TextJPN: 車はキィとブレーキを鳴らせて停まった。
TextENG: The car braked to a halt with a squeal.

TextJPN: 停まった先には何枚かの看板が見えた。
TextENG: Ahead of where we were stopped were several signs.

TextJPN: 『この先、私有地、関係者以外の立入を禁ず』
TextENG: ``Private Property Beyond. No Trespassing.``

TextJPN: 『毒ヘビ注意！　危険、引き返せ！』
TextENG: ``Beware of Poisonous Snakes! Danger! Turn Back!``

TextJPN: 『侵入者には、入山料として金百万円の証文に捺印していただきます』
TextENG: ``Intruders Will Be Charged An Entry Fee of 1,000,000 yen.``

TextJPN: そんなことを書いた何枚かの看板が立てられていた。
TextENG: Signs were erected there with things like that written on them.

TextJPN: 道路と森を隔てるように有刺鉄線の巻かれた金網が続いている…。
TextENG: The road was separated from the forest by a chain link fence wrapped in barbed wire...

TextJPN: 「…私有地なんで、ここまでです。@k@vS05/11/100700104.この先は、監視カメラがいくつも仕掛けられてます。@k@vS05/11/100700105.うっかり道に迷いました、なんて論法が通じる相手じゃありませんからねぇ」
TextENG: ``...Since this is private property, this is as far as we go.@k@vS05/11/100700104. There's several surveillance cameras set up further in.@k@vS05/11/100700105. Saying that we just got lost won't work with these guys.``

TextJPN: 「……この先が、そうなんですね？」
TextENG: ``...They're beyond here, right?``

TextJPN: 御三家の公由家でも、古手家でもなく、…現在の雛見沢村と鬼ヶ淵死守同盟を影から支配する、@k…最後の御三家。
TextENG: The people currently controlling Hinamizawa and the Onigafuchi Guardians were neither the Kimiyoshi family nor the Furude family, but@k the last of the three.

TextJPN: 「えぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700107.…この先にあるのが御三家のひとつ、園崎家。@k@vS05/11/100700108.…雛見沢村を影から支配する連中です」
TextENG: ``Yeah.@k@vS05/11/100700107. ...Beyond here is one of the Three Families, the Sonozaki family.@k@vS05/11/100700108. They're the ones controlling Hinamizawa from the shadows.``

TextJPN: …資料の中の幹部リストでも、御三家の姓を持つ名前は多かった。@k…もちろん、園崎も例外ではない。@kだが、トップは常に公由家だった。
TextENG: ...Among the list of executives recorded in the documents, the number of people with last names from the three families was quite high.@k ...Of course, Sonozaki was no exception.@k However, at the top was the Kimiyoshi family.

TextJPN: …表のトップが公由家なら、影のトップは園崎家。
TextENG: ...If the Kimiyoshi family seemed to be in charge, the rulers behind the scenes were the Sonozaki family.

TextJPN: この二重構造がすでに、…この村には、陽と陰のふたつの顔があることを暗に教えていた…。
TextENG: This double-layered structure implicitly told me that this village had both a light and a dark side...

TextJPN: 「園崎家の頂点は、現頭首の園崎お魎っていう婆さんです。@k@vS05/11/100700111.気をつけて下さいよ、大物です」
TextENG: ``The current head of the Sonozaki family is an old lady named Oryou.@k@vS05/11/100700111. Be careful, she's no small fry.``

TextJPN: 「市長だって最敬礼でお迎えするようなＶＩＰですからね。@k@vS05/11/100700113.…まぁ雛見沢と周辺の町に住む村の親族の数千の票田を固めてるわけですから、政治家は頭、上がらないんでしょうが。@k@vS05/11/100700114.んっふっふっふ！」
TextENG: ``She's enough of a VIP that even the mayor of the city has to bow before her.@k@vS05/11/100700113. ...Well, in Hinamizawa and the surrounding area their relatives amount to a block of several thousand votes. No politician could show disrespect for that.@k@vS05/11/100700114. Nfu fu fu!``

TextJPN: …話によれば園崎お魎という御仁は、この地方では園崎明王などと呼ばれるくらいにその発言には影響力があるそうだ。
TextENG: Rumor has it that Sonozaki Oryou's word has such influence in the region she's given names like Empress Sonozaki.

TextJPN: 「つまり、…その人物が、鬼ヶ淵死守同盟の事実上のトップということですね？」
TextENG: ``In other words... That would make her the actual leader of the Onigafuchi Guardians, right?``

TextJPN: 「そうなります」
TextENG: ``You've got it.``

TextJPN: 大石氏はそう言うと、懐から潰れかけた煙草の箱を取り出した。
TextENG: With those words, Ooishi pulled out a well-worn cigarette box.

TextJPN: ……大臣の孫の誘拐と脅迫疑惑。
TextENG: The suspected kidnapping of the Minister's grandchild and subsequent threats.

TextJPN: その裏には、雛見沢ダム計画撤回を目論む、鬼ヶ淵死守同盟の暗躍があるのだろうか…。
TextENG: Were these part of the hidden plot by the Onigafuchi Guardians in order to have the Hinamizawa Dam Project cancelled?

TextJPN: 「……あなた、東京からはるばる、調べにいらしたんですよねぇ？」
TextENG: ``...You came all the way from Tokyo to investigate this, didn't you?``

TextJPN: 「じゃあ、ほら、あれだ。@k@vS05/11/100700118.あの犬飼大臣への直訴事件の絡みですかな？@k@vS05/11/100700119.　ようするに、アレで要注意団体ってことで公安がマークすることになったと。@k@vS05/11/100700120.そういう感じですか？@k@vS05/11/100700121.　なっはっはっはっは」
TextENG: ``Ah, then...@k@vS05/11/100700118. Is it related to that direct appeal incident with Minister Inukai?@k@vS05/11/100700119. If that's the case, then Public Safety has them marked on a watchlist?@k@vS05/11/100700120. Something like that?@k@vS05/11/100700121. Na ha ha ha ha.``

TextJPN: 「大石さんこそ、…お察しが早くて助かります」
TextENG: ``Having you guess that so quickly makes this easy.``

TextJPN: 煙草の煙を吐き出しながら、大石氏は一本取られたかのように大きく笑った…。@k…と、思った笑いは、突然にぷっつりと途切れた。
TextENG: While exhaling out cigarette smoke, Ooishi smiled broadly, like I'd just pulled a good one on him...@k ...or so I thought. His smile disappeared suddenly.

TextJPN: 「嘘でしょ？」
TextENG: ``That's a lie, isn't it?``

TextJPN: 「だから、直訴事件でマークが付いたっての。@k@vS05/11/100700124.嘘でしょ？」
TextENG: ``I mean, the direct appeal putting them on a watchlist.@k@vS05/11/100700124. That's a lie, isn't it?``

TextJPN: 大石氏は、…直訴事件程度で、東京本庁から捜査官が派遣されるわけがない。
TextENG: Ooishi knew there was no way that Tokyo HQ would dispatch an investigator over something as minor as a direct appeal.

TextJPN: …派遣されるからには、何かもっと…大きな理由があると、そこまで踏んでいるのだ。
TextENG: ...If they were to dispatch someone, it had to be for a more... dire reason. He had figured out as much.

TextJPN: …私は表情に出さない方の部類の人間だと思っていた。@k…だが、彼の眼力の前には、私の胸の内は丸裸にされてしまっているのだろうか…。
TextENG: ...I thought of myself as the type of person who doesn't let things show on their face.@k In front of his watchful gaze, however, I felt that what I was thinking was completely laid bare...

TextJPN: 大石氏は沈黙し、重苦しい間で、私が口を割るのを待つかのように、新しい煙草に火をつける。
TextENG: Ooishi silently lit another cigarette, as if waiting for me to interject during this awkward pause.

TextJPN: …なるほど、…これが、ベテラン刑事の吐かせの技術ってわけか。
TextENG: ...I see... so this was a veteran detective's way of getting someone to spill information.

TextJPN: だが、そうと気付いてしまえばそれまでだ。
TextENG: But, as long as I realized this, there would be nothing more.

TextJPN: …ここで私が口を開かないことで、何も不利益を被ることはない。
TextENG: ...If I didn't open my mouth, I wouldn't have to lose anything.

TextJPN: …大石氏が根負けするまで、外ののどかな景色を満喫していればいいだけなのだから。
TextENG: All I had to do was stare out the window and enjoy the scenery until Ooishi gave up.

TextJPN: 「……んっふっふっふ！@k@vS05/11/100700126.　あなたって人は、本当に隠し事が下手な人ですねぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700127.そういう素直で初々しいの、悪くないなぁ」
TextENG: ``Nfu fu fu!@k@vS05/11/100700126. You really are bad at hiding things, you know.@k@vS05/11/100700127. Being so young and earnest isn't so bad.``

TextJPN: 私が一向に折れる様子を見せない為、３本目の煙草をもみ消し、大石が苦笑いした。
TextENG: Ooishi smirked as he twisted out his third cigarette, while I tried not to let him notice that I had yielded completely.

TextJPN: …初めは私の勝ちだと思ったが、大石には少なくとも、私が隠し事をしているという確信を与えてしまったのは間違いない。
TextENG: ...At first I'd thought I had won, but at the very least Ooishi had ascertained that I was hiding something.

TextJPN: …その意味においては、私はまんまと彼のペースにはめられたのかもしれない…。
TextENG: ...Meaning that I might have ended up marching to his tune.

TextJPN: 大石氏はエンジンを再び吹かし、車を動かした。
TextENG: Ooishi started up the engine once again, and began to move the car.

TextJPN: 「…素直なところを教えてくれりゃあ、もっとお力になれると思ったんですがね」
TextENG: ``...If you'd just been honest with me, I thought I might have been able to help you.``

TextJPN: 「……素直に話したら、どう力になれるんです？」
TextENG: ``...How would you help?``

TextJPN: どうせもう隠し事はバレているのだと思い、逆に話を振ってやることにする。
TextENG: If the cat was out of the bag, I might as well use it to catch some mice.

TextJPN: 「内容によりけりですがね、雛見沢界隈に詳しい情報屋に引き合わせてあげてもいいですよ」
TextENG: ``Well, this depends on what we're talking about, but I might be able to set you up with someone who's knowledgable about the goings-on in Hinamizawa.``

TextJPN: 「協力員、ですか？」
TextENG: ``An informant?``

TextJPN: 「…んっふっふっふ！@k@vS05/11/100700131.　そっかぁ、あんたらはそう呼ぶんでしたねぇ」
TextENG: ``...Nfu fu fu!@k@vS05/11/100700131. I see, is that what you call it?``

TextJPN: 「…どうして私の任務に興味を？@k@vS05/13/101300103.　大石さん」
TextENG: ``...Why are you interested in my case,@k@vS05/13/101300103. Ooishi-san?``

TextJPN: 「そりゃ、あんたと同じです。@k@vS05/11/100700133.…常に知るのが私たちの仕事じゃあありませんか」
TextENG: ``Well, I'm the same as you.@k@vS05/11/100700133. ...Isn't it our business to know things?``

TextJPN: …大石氏の情報屋と接触できる機会は、…この上なく魅力的だった。
TextENG: Being able to meet with Ooishi's informant was an extremely compelling opportunity.

TextJPN: 我々は土地勘のある人間に情報協力を依頼することで、相手を探る。
TextENG: We were looking to recruit somebody familiar with the area to collaborate with for intelligence.

TextJPN: 結局、人を知るには人に聞く以上の方法など存在しはしないのだ。
TextENG: In the end, there was no better method for finding people than asking.

TextJPN: だが、…我々は常に、一般警察などザルだと教えられている。
TextENG: We were always taught, however, that the rank-and-file police were no better than monkeys.

TextJPN: 我々と違い、守秘義務に怠慢でいい加減。
TextENG: Unlike us, they were careless with confidential cases.

TextJPN: 酔った勢いでどこで口走るかもわからない、…その程度だと見下している。
TextENG: We looked down on them like they'd run their mouth off in a drunken stupor.

TextJPN: …その中でも、特にアウトローに見える大石氏に、大臣の孫の誘拐のことを話してもいいものか、…迷った。
TextENG: ...Ooishi was an outlaw even amongst them. And here I was lost on whether or not I should tell him about the kidnapping of the minister's grandson.

TextJPN: 「…その情報協力員は、どの程度、鬼ヶ淵死守同盟に精通を？」
TextENG: ``...This informant, exactly how knowledgeable are they about the Onigafuchi Guardians?``

TextJPN: 「なっはっはっは！@k@vS05/11/100700135.　あんたも公安の人間ならわかるでしょ？@k@vS05/11/100700136.　そんなの、私の口から、たとえあなたにだって話せる訳ないじゃありませんか」
TextENG: ``Na ha ha ha!@k@vS05/11/100700135. If you're from Public Safety, you'd know, wouldn't you?@k@vS05/11/100700136. Something like that is something I can't just tell you.``

TextJPN: …………情報ソースは絶対秘密。
TextENG: ...Protect your sources.

TextJPN: これは、秘密情報を扱う者の大前提だ。
TextENG: That was the first principle of dealing with confidential information.

TextJPN: …その意味では、大石氏は少なくともザルではなさそうだった。
TextENG: ...In that regard, it seemed that Ooishi wasn't one of those monkeys.

TextJPN: ……信用し、…協力を頼むべきか、否か。
TextENG: Should I trust him, ask for his help, or not?

TextJPN: 「あなたは国、私は県に雇われてますがね。@k@vS05/11/100700138.私たちの職務はそう大きくは違わないと思っています。@k@vS05/11/100700139.…力になれると思うんですがねぇ」
TextENG: ``It's just that you work for the feds, and I work for the prefecture.@k@vS05/11/100700138. I don't think that our jobs are that different.@k@vS05/11/100700139. ...I think I can be of help.``

TextJPN: …だが、この老獪な男に限って、とても口上通りの善意で協力を申し出ているとは思い難い。
TextENG: ...However, I had trouble believing that this crafty old man would simply help me just like he claimed.

TextJPN: さて、どうしたものか…。
TextENG: Now, what to do....

TextJPN: 「…大石さんほどの方が無償で力になって下さるとは、ちょっと思いがたいですが…？」
TextENG: ``I find it hard to believe that someone of your standing would help me out without strings attached...``

TextJPN: 「なっはっはっはっは…。@k@vS05/11/100700141.そりゃ、下心がないわけじゃないです。@k@vS05/11/100700142.あんたらは確か、協力員に支払える謝礼用の予算を持ってますよねぇ？」
TextENG: ``Na ha ha ha ha...@k@vS05/11/100700141. Well, it's not like I'm completely without an ulterior motive.@k@vS05/11/100700142. As I recall, you guys have space in your budget allocated to pay informants, right?``

TextJPN: 「領収書不要な予算を。@k@vS05/11/100700144.…そいつでですね、情報屋との接触にかかるコストを、ちょいと、」
TextENG: ``Something you don't need to submit a receipt for.@k@vS05/11/100700144. ...Just a little bit of that would be the cost of meeting with the informant.``

TextJPN: 「つまり、情報屋と渡りをつける謝礼をあなたにお支払いしろ、ということですね？@k@vS05/13/101300107.　……取引内容が明快で助かります」
TextENG: ``In other words, give the compensation earmarked for the informant to you first?@k@vS05/13/101300107. ...Well, it helps that the details of this deal are so clear-cut.``

TextJPN: 下心も、ここまでしゃあしゃあと言えれば大したものだった。
TextENG: He certainly was something else for being able to brazenly state his ulterior motive like this.

TextJPN: 善意で協力を申し出られるより、対価も提示される方が取引はわかりやすい。@k…そういう日の当たらない取引のうまい男だと直感した。
TextENG: Rather than him doing this out of the kindness of his heart, everything was a lot clearer if he was being compensated for this deal.@k ...I felt that he was the type of man who was good at these backroom dealings.

TextJPN: 「誤解しないで下さいよ？@k@vS05/11/100700146.　お金が必要なのは、私にじゃなくて、情報屋になんですからね？@k@vS05/11/100700147.　まぁ、支払いの関係上、お金は私が預かりますがねぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700148.んっふっふ！」
TextENG: ``Don't misunderstand me, please.@k@vS05/11/100700146. It's not me who needs the money, it's the informant, okay?@k@vS05/11/100700147. Well, in regards to the payment, I'll be handling the money.@k@vS05/11/100700148. Nfu fu!``

TextJPN: 「支払いはいつ？」
TextENG: ``When do you want it?``

TextJPN: 「今すぐがいいですねぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700150.ないんなら明日でもいいんですよ？」
TextENG: ``Right now would be good.@k@vS05/11/100700150. If you don't have it on you, tomorrow works as well.``

TextJPN: …自分の財布とは異なるもう一つの財布を取り出した。
TextENG: ...I pulled out a wallet that was different from my personal one.

TextJPN: 相手から得られる情報の内容に応じて、甲・乙・丙と支払うおおよその金額が決められている。@k…今回の場合は前払いの上、相手からもたらされる情報の質が読めないので、そう多くは払えない…。
TextENG: The price was pretty much fixed depending on what kind of information I was paying for.@k ...In this case, the payment was up front. Also considering the fact I didn't know what kind of info I would get, I shouldn't pay too much...

TextJPN: そんなことを思案していると、大石氏が、にゅっと手を伸ばし、財布の中身を鷲掴みにした。
TextENG: When I suggested that, Ooishi suddenly stretched out his hand and tightly grasped the contents of the wallet.

TextJPN: 「こういう時はですね、ケチケチしない方がいいんです。@k@vS05/11/100700152.大丈夫大丈夫、損はさせませんから」
TextENG: ``At times like this, it's best you not be so stingy.@k@vS05/11/100700152. It's all right, it's all right, it won't go to waste.``

TextJPN: 「…………わかりました。@k@vS05/13/101300110.ケチケチしないことにします」
TextENG: ``....I understand.@k@vS05/13/101300110. I won't be stingy.``

TextJPN: 「で？@k@vS05/11/100700154.　調べたい情報は何です？@k@vS05/11/100700155.　内容によって多少、アプローチが変わることもありますので…」
TextENG: ``And?@k@vS05/11/100700154. What kind of information are you looking for?@k@vS05/11/100700155. Depending on what you what, how we approach this will probably change...``

TextJPN: 「………他言無用を誓ってもらえますか？@k@vS05/13/101300112.　大石さん」
TextENG: ``...You swear you won't spread this information to anybody else,@k@vS05/13/101300112. Ooishi-san?``

TextJPN: 「誓うまでもありませんよ。@k@vS05/11/100700157.私もあなたたちと同じ。@k@vS05/11/100700158.職務上知り得たことは他言できませんからね」
TextENG: ``I can't swear as much.@k@vS05/11/100700157. I'm the same as you.@k@vS05/11/100700158. I can't withhold information obtained during the course of my duties.``

TextJPN: 「なっはっはっはっは！@k@vS05/11/100700160.　わかりましたよ、誓います。@k@vS05/11/100700161.ここで聞くことは他言無用です」
TextENG: ``Na ha ha ha ha!@k@vS05/11/100700160. I got it, I swear.@k@vS05/11/100700161. Nothing here gets said anywhere else.``

TextJPN: 「それに、あなたのお陰でたまってたツケを全部返せるんですからねぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700163.私は少なくとも金の絡んだ約束は絶対に違えませんよ？@k@vS05/11/100700164.　んっふっふっふ…！」
TextENG: ``On top of that, thanks to you, I can pay back what I owe from my mahjong debts.@k@vS05/11/100700163. In any case, I won't break a promise that involves money.@k@vS05/11/100700164. Nfu fu fu!``

TextJPN: 我ながら悪趣味が過ぎるという思いもある。
TextENG: I feel that I have too much bad taste.

TextJPN: だが、…良し悪しはともかくとしても、この提案に私は興味を覚えた。
TextENG: But... for better or worse, this suggestion intrigued me.

TextJPN: 「わかりました。@k@vS05/13/VX_akasaka_0003.内容次第では検討します。@k@vS05/13/VX_akasaka_0004.…それで？@k@vS05/13/VX_akasaka_0005.　あなた方の握っている情報はどんなものなんですか？」
TextENG: ``Understood.@k@vS05/13/VX_akasaka_0003. I will consider it depending on the content.@k@vS05/13/VX_akasaka_0004. So...?@k@vS05/13/VX_akasaka_0005. What kind of information do you people have in your hands?``

TextJPN: 「なっはっはっはっ！@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0002.　いきなり高いところから話してくる人だなぁ。@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0003.そんな言われようだと、こっちも考え直さないといけませんかねぇ～？」
TextENG: ``Nahahaha!@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0002. You're talking to me like you have the higher ground.@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0003. If that's the way it is, I guess I'll have to reconsider it~.``

TextJPN: 「…どういう意味です？」
TextENG: ``...What do you mean?``

TextJPN: むっ、と不快を感じて、私は大石氏を一瞥する。…彼も笑みをたたえながら、凄むようにずい、っと身を乗り出してきて言った。
TextENG: Feeling uncomfortable, I glance at Ooishi. …He also smiled and leaned forward and said, terrifyingly.

TextJPN: 「東京じゃあどうだか知りませんがね、…こういう現場でものを言うのは勘と人脈です。@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0005.肩書きとかキャリアなんて、なーんの役にも立ちませんから」
TextENG: ``I don't know how it is in Tokyo, but... what counts in a field like this is intuition and personal connections.@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0005. Titles and careers are of no use to you.``

TextJPN: 「そんな状況で情報を集めたところで、何か使えそうなお話が聞けると思いますか？」
TextENG: ``Do you think you'll get anything useful out of gathering information under those circumstances?``

TextJPN: 「…つまりあなたは、私に頭を下げて頼んでもおかしくない立場にいるんですよ。@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0008.おわかりいただけましたか？@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0009.　だから口の利きようには、もうちょっと気を遣っていただけると助かるんですがねぇ？」
TextENG: ``I mean, you're in a position where you could bow to me and ask for help.@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0008. Do you understand?@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0009. So it would be great if you could be a little more careful about how you talk to me.``

TextJPN: 言葉は丁寧だが、ふてぶてしいまでに挑発的な言い方。
TextENG: The words are polite, but they are provocative to the point of being offensive.

TextJPN: 一瞬頭にも来たが、…思い返してみると、確かに見知らぬ土地で私のできることは非常に少ない。彼の言うとおりだった。
TextENG: For a moment I was pissed, but then I thought back and realized that there was indeed very little I could do in a strange land. He was right.

TextJPN: 「…失礼しました。@k@vS05/13/VX_akasaka_0009.少々血が猛って、不遜な物言いをしてしまったようです。@k@vS05/13/VX_akasaka_0010.お許しいただけるとありがたいのですが」
TextENG: ``...I'm sorry.@k@vS05/13/VX_akasaka_0009. It seems that my blood was a little raging and I spoke out of turn.@k@vS05/13/VX_akasaka_0010. I hope you'll forgive me.``

TextJPN: 「いやいや、こちらこそ。@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0011.でも、素直なのはいいことです。@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0012.あなたはまだ若い、まだ修正の機会はいくらでもあるんですからな。@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0013.なっはっはっはっ！」
TextENG: ``No, no. I hope you too.@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0011. But it's good to be honest.@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0012. You're still young, and there's still plenty of opportunity for correction.@k@vS05/11/VX_oishi_0013. Nahahaha!``

TextJPN: そして大石氏は、情報屋を利用するにあたって必要となる『経費』の相場について話をしてくれた。
TextENG: Ooishi-san then talked about the market price of the ``expenses`` required to use an informant.

TextJPN: まぁ、そのうちの何割かは彼の懐に入るのかもしれないが、それくらいは許容範囲だろう。
TextENG: Well, maybe a percentage of that will go into his pocket, but that's about as acceptable as it gets.

TextJPN: …自分の財布とは異なるもう一つの財布を取り出した。
TextENG: ...I pulled out a wallet that was different from my personal one.

TextJPN: 相手から得られる情報の内容に応じて、甲・乙・丙と支払うおおよその金額が決められている。@k…今回の場合は前払いの上、相手からもたらされる情報の質が読めないので、そう多くは払えない…。
TextENG: The price was pretty much fixed depending on what kind of information I was paying for.@k ...In this case, the payment was up front. Also considering the fact I didn't know what kind of info I would get, I shouldn't pay too much...

TextJPN: そんなことを思案していると、大石氏が、にゅっと手を伸ばし、財布の中身を鷲掴みにした。
TextENG: When I suggested that, Ooishi suddenly stretched out his hand and tightly grasped the contents of the wallet.

TextJPN: 「こういう時はですね、ケチケチしない方がいいんです。@k@vS05/11/100700152.大丈夫大丈夫、損はさせませんから」
TextENG: ``At times like this, it's best you not be so stingy.@k@vS05/11/100700152. It's all right, it's all right, it won't go to waste.``

TextJPN: 「…………わかりました。@k@vS05/13/101300110.ケチケチしないことにします」
TextENG: ``....I understand.@k@vS05/13/101300110. I won't be stingy.``

TextJPN: 「で？@k@vS05/11/100700154.　調べたい情報は何です？@k@vS05/11/100700155.　内容によって多少、アプローチが変わることもありますので…」
TextENG: ``And?@k@vS05/11/100700154. What kind of information are you looking for?@k@vS05/11/100700155. Depending on what you what, how we approach this will probably change...``

TextJPN: 「………他言無用を誓ってもらえますか？@k@vS05/13/101300112.　大石さん」
TextENG: ``...You swear you won't spread this information to anybody else,@k@vS05/13/101300112. Ooishi-san?``

TextJPN: 「誓うまでもありませんよ。@k@vS05/11/100700157.私もあなたたちと同じ。@k@vS05/11/100700158.職務上知り得たことは他言できませんからね」
TextENG: ``I can't swear as much.@k@vS05/11/100700157. I'm the same as you.@k@vS05/11/100700158. I can't withhold information obtained during the course of my duties.``

TextJPN: 「なっはっはっはっは！@k@vS05/11/100700160.　わかりましたよ、誓います。@k@vS05/11/100700161.ここで聞くことは他言無用です」
TextENG: ``Na ha ha ha ha!@k@vS05/11/100700160. I got it, I swear.@k@vS05/11/100700161. Nothing here gets said anywhere else.``

TextJPN: 「それに、あなたのお陰でたまってたツケを全部返せるんですからねぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700163.私は少なくとも金の絡んだ約束は絶対に違えませんよ？@k@vS05/11/100700164.　んっふっふっふ…！」
TextENG: ``On top of that, thanks to you, I can pay back what I owe from my mahjong debts.@k@vS05/11/100700163. In any case, I won't break a promise that involves money.@k@vS05/11/100700164. Nfu fu fu!``

TextJPN: 信用していいか、最後の最後まで揺れたが、…結局、折れることにした。
TextENG: I was still unsure if I should trust him until the very last moment... but in the end, I broke down.

TextJPN: 大石氏は１００％信用できるような男じゃないが、…裏事情に精通しているのは間違いない。@k…自分に与えられた任務を迅速にこなすには、協力を求めたい相手だ。
TextENG: Ooishi wasn't the type of guy I could trust 100%, but there was no mistaking he had access to underground information networks.@k In order to accomplish my mission swiftly, I needed his cooperation.

TextJPN: …私は、覚悟を決めることにする。
TextENG: ...I set my resolve.

TextJPN: 「…鬼ヶ淵死守同盟が、ある事件に関与しているか否かを調査しています」
TextENG: ``I'm investigating whether or not the Onigafuchi Guardians is related to a certain incident.``

TextJPN: 「ある事件？」
TextENG: ``Certain incident?``

TextJPN: 「犬飼建設大臣が、何者かに脅迫を受けている可能性があります」
TextENG: ``There's a possibility that the Minister of Construction, Inuaik, is being coerced by someone.``

TextJPN: 「…可能性とはまた、遠回しな言い方ですねぇ」
TextENG: ``...Saying there's a possibility is kind of a roundabout way of putting it.``

TextJPN: 「大臣の近辺に内通者がいるらしいのです。@k@vS05/13/101300117.その内通者によって、高度に監視されているらしく、大臣は脅迫初期から屈服している様子です。@k@vS05/13/101300118.警察へも我々へも一切通報していません」
TextENG: ``It appears there's a mole close to the minister.@k@vS05/13/101300117. And due to that mole, the minister had been monitored quite thoroughly, and was seemingly forced to cede to their threats right away.@k@vS05/13/101300118. None of this was reported to us or the police.``

TextJPN: 「…なるほど。@k@vS05/11/100700168.だから脅迫を受けている可能性、という言い方になると。@k@vS05/11/100700169.……だとすると妙ですねぇ？@k@vS05/11/100700170.　大臣が誰にも通報していないなら、どうしてあんたらは事件を知ったんです？」
TextENG: ``...I see.@k@vS05/11/100700168. So that's why you're saying there's only a possibilty he's being coerced.@k@vS05/11/100700169. ...In that case, isn't it a little strange?@k@vS05/11/100700170. If the minister didn't report this to anybody, how did you guys know about this incident?``

TextJPN: 大臣のプライベートを監視しない限り、発覚などしない。
TextENG: If we didn't spy on the minister's private life, we would have never found out.

TextJPN: 「…その説明は、私が情報屋に提供する必要がないと思われるので割愛します」
TextENG: ``...I don't think we have to provide that explanation to the informant, so I'm omitting it.``

TextJPN: 大石氏は勘付いているらしく、私が説明を拒むと、くっくっくと声を殺して笑った。
TextENG: Ooishi had apparently caught on, and quietly chuckled when I refused to explain.

TextJPN: 「なるほど。@k@vS05/11/100700172.…大臣の近辺にスパイがいるらしいから、公安だけの極秘調査ということになったわけですか。@k@vS05/11/100700173.……そりゃあ確かに穏便な話じゃないですねぇ」
TextENG: ``I see.@k@vS05/11/100700172. ...There's a spy close to the minister, so Public Safety made it a highly classified investigation.@k@vS05/11/100700173. That certainly isn't a very amicable story, is it.``

TextJPN: 「事を公にすれば、大臣の政治生命も含め、政変に発展する可能性は極めて高いでしょう。@k@vS05/13/101300121.犯人グループの目的がそこにあるならば、由々しき事態に発展する可能性があります」
TextENG: ``If this matter became public, not only would this affect the minister's political career, but the possibility of there being a shift in the political landscape is extremely high.@k@vS05/13/101300121. If the perpetrators' aim is indeed that, then this could develop into a very grave situation.``

TextJPN: 「……政府の列島改造は、まぁいろいろ方々との衝突も多いらしいですからねぇ。@k@vS05/11/100700175.どんなささやかなケチでもひとつ付けば、…野党勢力がどっと票を伸ばす可能性もある、と」
TextENG: ``...Well, with the government having development projects all over the country, they've butted heads with quite a few people.@k@vS05/11/100700175. It wouldn't take much wrongdoing for the left wing parties to suddenly garner more support.``

TextJPN: 「大臣がどのような要求を受けているのかは現在調査中です。@k@vS05/13/101300123.ですが脅迫の方法だけはほぼわかっています」
TextENG: ``We're currently investigating what demands are being forced on the minister.@k@vS05/13/101300123. But at least we have a good idea of how he's being threatened.``

TextJPN: 「…何です？」
「大臣の孫の、誘拐です。@k@vS05/13/101300125.周辺は否定していますが、最後の目撃から見て、すでに誘拐後７２時間が経過していると思われます」
TextENG: ``The minister's grandson... was kidnapped.@k@vS05/13/101300125. They're denying it, but judging from when he was last seen, it's believed it's already been over 72 hours since the kidnapping.``

TextJPN: 「３日ですか。@k@vS05/11/100700178.……並みの、身代金目的ならもう決着してますねぇ」
TextENG: ``So, three days.@k@vS05/11/100700178. ...If they were just after ransom money, this would have been settled by now.``

TextJPN: 「金銭でなく、大臣に何らかの政治的なアクションを要求している可能性が極めて高いでしょう。@k@vS05/13/101300127.……それを我々は黙認するわけには行きません」
TextENG: ``It may be this isn't for monetary gain. The possibility that they're forcing the minister to do something politically is extremely high.@k@vS05/13/101300127. ...That's something we just can't consent to.``

TextJPN: 「で、それの犯人グループとの可能性として、鬼ヶ淵死守同盟がリストに挙がったわけですね」
TextENG: ``So then, the Onigafuchi Guardians was listed as one of the possible perpetrators.``

TextJPN: 「そうです」
TextENG: ``That is correct.``

TextJPN: 「……………大臣の孫を誘拐して、ダム計画の撤回を求める、か…。@k@vS05/11/100700181.…んんん……」
TextENG: ``...Kidnap the minister's grandson, and demand the cancellation of the dam project...@k@vS05/11/100700181. Hmm...``

TextJPN: 「どうでしょう大石さん。@k@vS05/13/101300130.…その可能性は、あなたから見て、ありえると思いますか？」
TextENG: ``What do you think, Ooishi-san?@k@vS05/13/101300130. ...From your point of view, do you think that's possible?``

TextJPN: 大石氏はしばらくの間、考えるような仕草を見せながら小さく唸っていた。
TextENG: Ooishi seemed to ponder the idea for a while.

TextJPN: 同じ問い掛けをした時、中部局の室長は『ありえる』と即答した。
TextENG: The section chief at the regional office had responded immediately with: ``It's possible.``

TextJPN: …なのに、これだけ精通している大石氏は、うなり始める…。
TextENG: ...However Ooishi, who was this well-informed about the matter, was hemming and hawing...

TextJPN: …やがて、ぽつりと。
TextENG: ...Finally, just a little bit...

TextJPN: …本当にぽつりと妙なことを言い出した。
TextENG: ...He said something that was really just a little bit strange.

TextJPN: 「…………明治前まではですね。@k@vS05/11/100700183.この辺りは雛見沢村って名前じゃなくて、鬼ヶ淵村って呼ばれてたそうです」
TextENG: ``...This was before the Meiji Era, you see.@k@vS05/11/100700183. This area wasn't named Hinamizawa Village back then--it was called Onigafuchi.``

TextJPN: 「…なははは、うちの婆さまの受け売りですがね」
TextENG: ``...Nahahaha, this is just what I heard from my grandmother.``

TextJPN: …つい直前までしていた、大臣の孫の誘拐事件の話とは何も噛み合わず、…突然の話題に面食らってしまう。
TextENG: ...This topic was so completely and suddenly unrelated to the subject of the kidnapping of the minister's grandson that I was taken slightly aback.

TextJPN: 「鬼ヶ淵村？@k@vS05/13/101300132.　……あ、…それで鬼ヶ淵死守同盟という名称になったわけですね」
TextENG: ``Onigafuchi?@k@vS05/13/101300132. ...Oh, so that's why they're called the Onigafuchi Guardians.``

TextJPN: 「…鬼ヶ淵村ってのはですね、人食い鬼の住む村だと言われてたんだそうです。@k@vS05/11/100700186.今でも村人は、自分の体に鬼の血が半分流れてると信じてます」
TextENG: ``...You see, the village of Onigafuchi was said to be inhabited by demons that devoured humans.@k@vS05/11/100700186. Even now, it's believed that the blood of these demons partially courses through the veins of the villagers.``

TextJPN: 「ひ、…人食い鬼…？？@k@vS05/13/101300134.　大石さん、…それ、…何の話ですか？」
TextENG: ``...D-Demons that devour humans??@k@vS05/13/101300134. Ooishi-san... what are you saying?``

TextJPN: 「情報ですよ、情報。@k@vS05/11/100700188.さっきあなたからたくさんもらっちゃいましたからね。@k@vS05/11/100700189.少しもらい過ぎました。@k@vS05/11/100700190.その分、サービスしてあげてるんですよ」
TextENG: ``It's information.@k@vS05/11/100700188. I got a lot from you just now.@k@vS05/11/100700189. A little too much.@k@vS05/11/100700190. In exchange, I'm giving you a little freebie.``

TextJPN: 大石氏はにやっと笑ったが、別にふざけた様子ではなかった。
TextENG: Ooishi finally smiled, but it didn't seem like he was fooling around.

TextJPN: 「……………先を続けてください」
TextENG: ``...Please continue.``

TextJPN: 「人食い鬼たちはですね。@k@vS05/11/100700192.普段は仙人と崇められて、ひっそりと暮らしているんですがね。@k@vS05/11/100700193.…やっぱり人食いですから、定期的に麓の村に下りてきては、獲物をさらっていったんだそうです」
TextENG: ``You see,  these human-devouring demons...@k@vS05/11/100700192. Normally they were were revered as Taoist 'transcendants', and lived tucked away from the rest of the world.@k@vS05/11/100700193. ...But they ate people, after all, so apparently they'd go to villages in the foothills regularly and abduct their prey.``

TextJPN: 「…それをですね、『鬼隠し』と言いまして」
TextENG: ``...They used to call that being 'demoned away', or 'Onikakushi'.``

TextJPN: 鬼隠し…。
TextENG: Demoned away...

TextJPN: ……初めて聞く不思議な単語だった。
TextENG: ...It was the first time I heard such a peculiar phrase.

TextJPN: だが、人食い鬼が、犠牲者をさらうという恐ろしい内容に、一抹の不気味さを感じる。
TextENG: However, I felt something slightly ominous from this horrifying tale of demons abducting people in order to eat them.

TextJPN: 「…ほら、よく世間一般に『神隠し』っていうのがあるじゃないですか。@k@vS05/11/100700196.人が、ある日突然、失踪してしまうとそう言うでしょう。@k@vS05/11/100700197.…この辺りでは同じことがあると『鬼隠し』って呼ぶんです」
TextENG: ``...Look, you know how there's the common phrase 'spirited away'?@k@vS05/11/100700196. When people suddenly go missing one day, they call it that.@k@vS05/11/100700197. ...When the same thing happens around here, they call it being 'demoned away'.``

TextJPN: 「…………その昔話と本件に何か関係が？」
TextENG: ``...How does that old tale relate to the matter at hand?``

TextJPN: 「…いえいえ。@k@vS05/11/100700199.直接的には何の関係もない、ただのおしゃべりですがね。@k@vS05/11/100700200.…ただ」
TextENG: ``...Oh no.@k@vS05/11/100700199. There's no direct relationship, I'm just making some small talk here.@k@vS05/11/100700200. It's just...``

TextJPN: 車が揺れる。@k…いつの間にか砂利道は舗装道路に変わっていた。
TextENG: The car shook.@k ...At some point the gravel road had changed to a paved one.

TextJPN: 「ただ？　何です？」
TextENG: ``It's just...? Just what?``

TextJPN: 「…この土地に『鬼隠し』という名の、失踪・誘拐を暗示するキーワードがある、ということだけは、お話しておこうと思いまして。@k@vS05/11/100700202.今回の大臣の孫の誘拐と関係あるかはわかりませんがね」
TextENG: ``...That around here, the phrase 'demoned away' is somewhat of a code for disappearances and kidnappings. I just thought I'd mention that.@k@vS05/11/100700202. I don't know if this has anything to do with the kidnapping of the minister's grandson.``

TextJPN: 「……まぁ、深い話ではないんです。@k@vS05/11/100700204.そんな謂れの話がある、ということだけでもね、んっふっふっふっふ…！」
TextENG: ``...Well, there's no deep meaning behind it.@k@vS05/11/100700204. It's just, there's that little bit of history, nfu fu fu fu....!``

TextJPN: 人食い鬼たちが、…獲物をさらいに麓に下りてくる行為、『鬼隠し』
TextENG: ``Onikakushi``... human-eating demons coming down to the foothills and abducting their prey.

TextJPN: では…自分たちの住まう村を水没させようとするダム計画を撤回させるため、…その制裁として大臣の孫をさらって…『鬼隠し』にした？
TextENG: Then... in order to cancel the dam project that threatened to submerge the village they lived in, did they 'demon away' the minister's grandson?

TextJPN: …なら、…見せしめに大臣の孫はもう…鬼たちに食い殺されている…？？
TextENG: ...Then, had they already made an example out of the minister's grandson and eaten him alive??

TextJPN: 「…ははははは。@k@vS05/13/101300139.ちょっと興味深い昔話ですね」
TextENG: ``...Hahahahaha.@k@vS05/13/101300139. It's a bit of an interesting old tale, isn't it?``

TextJPN: 「鬼たちの村にみだりに踏み入れば、たちまち囚われ食い殺される。@k@vS05/11/100700206.だから鬼ヶ淵村には近付くな」
TextENG: ``If you set foot into the demons' village without reason, you'll promptly be captured and eaten alive.@k@vS05/11/100700206. So don't go near Onigafuchi.``

TextJPN: 「……今時の若者はこんな迷信、信じませんがね。@k@vS05/11/100700208.興宮の明治生まれの年寄り連中には、今でも真面目に信じてるのが多いですよ」
TextENG: ``...Kids these days wouldn't have these superstitions, would they?@k@vS05/11/100700208. Even amongst the older folk in Okinomiya born in the Meiji Era, there's quite a few who wouldn't heed these warnings.``

TextJPN: 周囲の人たちに恐れられている、雛見沢村。@k…県警公安で聞いた情報のひとつを思い出す。
TextENG: Hinamizawa Village was feared by the people in the area.@k I recalled that piece of information I heard from the Prefectural Public Safety Division.

TextJPN: 「何しろこの辺は田舎ですからね。@k@vS05/11/100700210.迷信なんかが平気で幅を利かせてるんです」
TextENG: ``In any case, we're in the boonies out here.@k@vS05/11/100700210. It's kind of expected that there'd be some superstitions around.``

TextJPN: 「なっはっはっはっは！@k@vS05/11/100700212.　東京から来られた赤坂さんには、ちょっと想像も付かないでしょうがねぇ」
TextENG: ``Na ha ha ha ha!@k@vS05/11/100700212. Somebody from Tokyo like you, Akasaka-san, probably couldn't even begin to imagine it, could you?``

TextJPN: …人食い鬼が、自分たちの村を侵した代償として、大臣の孫をさらい、…食い殺した。
TextENG: ...The man-eating demons, as the price for violating the sanctity of their village, kidnapped the minister's grandson... and swallowed him whole.

TextJPN: そんな突拍子もない考えが浮かぶ。
TextENG: That ludicrous idea flew through my head.

TextJPN: …あまりの下らない想像に、自分でも半ば呆れてしまう。
TextENG: ...It was so absurd, I was half-disgusted with myself.

TextJPN: 大石氏にからかわれただけだ。
TextENG: Ooishi was just teasing me.

TextJPN: …下らない。@k本当に下らない。
TextENG: ...Stupid.@k It was all really so stupid.

TextJPN: ……思えば、私はもうこの時に、この怪しげな村の呪縛に囚われていたのかもしれない。
TextENG: ...Come to think of it, by then, I may have already been seized by the curse of that dubious village.

TextJPN: …それに気付くのには、…もう少しの時間が必要だった…。
TextENG: ...For me to realize that... would take a little more time..
